bestBHT.bht: The disciples of John inquire about the disparity in behavior between themselves, who frequently fast and offer prayers, and the disciples of Jesus, who instead eat and drink. The discerning observers note the stark contrast in the practices of the two groups, highlighting the meticulous and concentrated nature of the prayers of John's disciples. These supplications are not mere routine prayers, but rather, are deeply petitionary in nature. This interrogation underscores the notable disparities between the followers of John and Jesus in their respective religious practices and rituals.

Henry Alford: On the difference in the persons who ask this question, see on Matthew and Mark."
and make prayers: see ch. xi. 1.
These prayers must be understood in connexion with an ascetic form of life, not as only the usual prayers of devout men.
Marvin Vincent: The word [πυκνα] literally means close-packed, as a thicket, or the plumage of a bird.
Philip Schaff: And they said to him...The disciples of John, etc. This is not in the form of a question." (Luke 5:33).
It refers to stated prayers, like those of ascetics." (Luke 5:33).
Archibald T. Robertson: Often (πυκνα). Only in Luke. Common word for thick, compact, often.
And make supplications (κα δεησεις ποιουντα). Only in Luke.
But thine (ο δε σο). Sharp contrast between the conduct of the disciples of Jesus and those of John and the Pharisees who here appear together as critics of Christ and his disciples.
John Gill: Why do the disciples of John fast often, and make prayers?
Why do the disciples of John baptize frequently, fast, and make prayers?
John Wesley: Make prayers — Long and solemn. Matthew 9:14; Mark 2:18.

bhtAttempts.bht: The question of why the disciples of John fast often and make prayers while the disciples of Jesus eat and drink is raised in this verse. The commentators note the contrast between the two groups, highlighting the ascetic practices of John's disciples and the more relaxed behavior of Jesus' disciples. The prayers mentioned are understood to be not just ordinary prayers, but rather an integral part of an ascetic lifestyle. The use of the word supplications emphasizes the petitionary nature of these prayers. Ultimately, this question serves to highlight the differences in conduct between the disciples of John and the disciples of Jesus.

The disciples of John question why they fast often and make prayers, while Jesus' disciples eat and drink. The commentators note the contrast in behavior, with John's disciples practicing asceticism and offering more solemn prayers. They emphasize that these prayers are not ordinary, but rather petitionary in nature. This inquiry brings attention to the different conduct between the followers of John and Jesus.

The disciples of John ask why they fast often and make prayers, while Jesus' disciples eat and drink. The commentators mention the contrast between the two groups and the ascetic practices of John's disciples, who engage in close-packed and solemn prayers. They highlight the petitionary nature of these supplications. This question serves to highlight the distinct behavior of the disciples of John and Jesus, drawing attention to their different approaches to faith and devotion.

The disciples of John inquire about the disparity in behavior between themselves, who frequently fast and offer prayers, and the disciples of Jesus, who instead eat and drink. The discerning observers note the stark contrast in the practices of the two groups, highlighting the meticulous and concentrated nature of the prayers of John's disciples. These supplications are not mere routine prayers, but rather, are deeply petitionary in nature. This interrogation underscores the notable disparities between the followers of John and Jesus in their respective religious practices and rituals.

The disciples of John raise the question of why they engage in frequent fasting and offer prayers while Jesus' disciples eat and drink. The commentators point out the contrasting conduct between the two groups, emphasizing the diligent and intensive nature of John's disciples' prayers. These supplications are not merely customary but rather heartfelt and petitionary. This inquiry serves as a reminder of the distinctions in behavior between those who follow John and those who follow Jesus, highlighting their varying approaches to religious devotion.
